MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Coastal Protection.

Qst.askee: Minister for Communications, Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the position regarding cliff stabilisation at Dock Road and Island Lane, Dunmore East, County Waterford (details supplied).

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Communications, Marine and Natural Resources (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The position is that my Department in conjunction with consultants are re-examining the level of works necessary to stabilise the cliff at Dock Road. Any works proposed for the stabilisation will be undertaken so as not to interfere with the nesting habitat of the kittiwake colony. If possible, a scheme will be designed to improve the nesting conditions for the birds. I have allocated funding in respect of cliff stabilisation works at the Dock Road and Island Road this year.

MainHeading.P: In regard to the work at Island Lane, Waterford County Council has advised that, as this work is reinstatement and repair work, planning permission is not required. Negotiations are currently in progress with contractors with a view to commencing the works next month. It is hoped to have the Island Lane works completed in early summer.

Qst.askee: Minister for Communications, Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: when a person (details supplied) in County Mayo will receive a forestry premium grant which they believe is due; the position in relation to same; and when this person's application form will issue for this year's grant.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Communications, Marine and Natural Resources (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The person in question is in receipt of a forestry compensatory allowance payment from the Department of Agriculture and Food. Application forms for this scheme will be issued by the forest service in June of this year as normal. On receipt of signed application form from the person in question payment will be made by the Department of Agriculture and Food in due course.

Qst.hpid: Mr. F. McGrath Mr. F. McGrath
Qst.Quest: his views on whether it is acceptable that a hospital (details supplied) in Dublin 3 is proposing to sell land at the rear of 57-67 Griffith Court, Dublin 3, to a private developer.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T. O'Malley Mr. T. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Mr. T. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: St. Vincent's Hospital, Fairview, Dublin 3, is a voluntary hospital set up by a private charitable trust, St. Vincent's Hospital Trust, and I therefore have no function in relation to any proposal by the hospital to sell the land in question.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Services for People with Disabilities.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: his estimate of the outstanding needs for services both residential, day care and therapeutic for persons with an intellectual disability; his estimate of the average waiting time in relation to these services for persons for whom a need is identified today; and the details of the new investment in place for services being made in 2003 to fill the gap in services.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T. O'Malley Mr. T. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Mr. T. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: Additional funding of €13.3 million has been allocated to services for persons with an intellectual disability or autism in 2003 to meet the full year cost of the 2002 developments and to further enhance the health related support services to children with an intellectual disability or autism. This funding is in addition to the very significant revenue investment, amounting to €188 million, which has been made in these services since 1997 and which is built into the ongoing budget base. The additional funding provided by this and the previous Government between 2000 and 2002 was used to put in place, in addition to a range of other services, over 900 new residential, 380 new respite and around 2,000 new day places for people with an intellectual disability and those with autism. In April 2000, information from the national intellectual disability database indicated that in the period 2000 to 2004, 1,711 new residential places were required to meet the identified needs for these services. The annual report is compiled from the regional datasets provided by the Eastern Regional Health Authority and the health boards. A delay in the submission of one regional dataset meant it was not possible to compile the information which forms the basis for the annual report. This was the case in relation to both 2001 and 2002. The 2001 report from the national intellectual disability database is currently with the printers and will be published within the next few weeks. The 2002 report will be available by early summer.

MainHeading.P: While the impact of the 2000 development programme is reflected in the 2001 data, this data does not reflect a significant reduction in the number of persons seeking residential services in particular in the period 2002 to 2006. The 2002 data, which will reflect the impact of the 2001 development programme are currently being collated and validated. In April 2000, information from the national intellectual disability database indicated that in the period 2000 to 2004, 912 new day places were required to meet the identified needs for these services. The 2001 data indicates that a similar number of new day places are required over the period 2002 to 2006. It should be noted that in addition to the day places required to meet the needs of those awaiting placement in the services as mentioned above, the additional funding allocated in recent years also provided for those requiring a change in day services. These include young people leaving school and requiring rehabilitative training places or those moving from rehabilitative training to other areas of the services such as sheltered work, activation or services for older people.

Despite the very significant investment in services in recent years, demographic factors are contributing to growing waiting lists for residential services in particular, even though the number of people in receipt of services, including full time residential services, continues to increase. The increased birth rate in the 1960s and 1970s has resulted in large numbers of adults in their late 20s and early 30s requiring full-time residential services. In addition, people with an intellectual disability are living longer than previously, adding to the need for services compared to previous generations. A review of the waiting lists between 1997 and 1999, conducted by the Health Research Board and published in the 1999 annual report from the national intellectual disability database, showed that while 269 people from the original waiting list of 1,439 received full time residential services in the period, the waiting list had grown by an additional 238 places, that is, 507 had joined the waiting list in the period. This has also been the international experience in service provision to this population. The overall economic position in 2003 has had implications for all aspects of public investment, and this is reflected in the Estimates and budget adopted by the Government for 2003. Within this overall framework, however, some two thirds of the additional funding available for non-capital investment in services has been allocated to the health services. This funding is being applied largely to maintaining existing levels of service across all service programmes, including services for people with an intellectual disability. While it is regrettable that the level of investment in these services achieved in recent years could not be maintained in 2003, my Department will work closely with the health boards and other service providers in relation to service provision this year.

In relation to the Deputy's query regarding estimated average waiting times for persons for whom a need is identified, I cannot give specific commitments for 2004 and onwards in relation to any element of the health services as these issues form part of the annual Estimates and budget discussions between my Department and the Department of Finance.

Qst.Quest: if there is an embargo on the various health boards in the recruitment of speech and language therapists, psychologists, social workers, radiographers, occupational therapists, nurses registered with An Bord Altranas, and physiotherapists fully validated; if any of these positions are being filled by health boards or if there is a waiting list for any of these positions; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Martin Mr. Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: There is no embargo on recruitment imposed by my Department. The chief executive officer of each individual health board has responsibility for the management of the workforce, including the appropriate staffing mix and the precise grades of staff employed within that board, in line with service plan priorities, subject to overall employment levels remaining within the authorised ceiling. The Deputy may wish to note the increase of in excess of 28,000, 42%, in the approved employment ceiling for the health services since 1997 bringing the current authorised employment ceiling to 96,000, excluding home helps.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Psychological Service.

Qst.Quest: the position in relation to the Government's commitment to implement the report of the joint review group in respect of psychological services.

his views on the joint review group's recommendation for psychological services, in view of the Government's commitment to implement same and its failure to do so; when he intends to proceed with these recommendations; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Martin Mr. Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 302 and 308 together.

The report of the joint review group on psychological services in the health services was published in March 2002. My Department is currently supporting the implementation of a key recommendation of the report relating to human resource planning through the provision of an additional 30 training places in clinical psychology. This represents a doubling in the number of trainee clinical psychologists employed in the health services.

MainHeading.P: I understand that, following a request received from my Department, the director of the health boards executive has undertaken to work with the directors of human resources in the health boards to develop an approach to facilitate the implementation of the recommendations of the joint review group. This will be undertaken in the light of service imperatives, funding priorities and relevant developments such as the recommendations on investment in education and training included in the action plan for people management published in November 2002.

Qst.Quest: when a follow up appointment will be arranged for a person (details supplied) in County Kildare; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Martin Mr. Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Responsibility for the provision of health services for persons living in counties Dublin, Kildare and Wicklow rests with the Eastern Regional Health Authority. My Department has, therefore, asked the regional chief executive of the authority to investigate the position in relation to this case and to reply to the Deputy directly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Security of the Elderly.

Qst.hpid: Ms M. Wallace Ms M. Wallace
Qst.Quest: if there is any health board scheme which provides funding towards the cost of an alarm for an elderly woman living alone; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Callely Mr. Callely
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Mr. Callely)
Speaker.P: The health boards and the ERHA have no formal funding scheme for the provision of alarms for older people. The Department of Communications, Marine and Natural Resources has confirmed that it provides funding for voluntary organisations which are involved in identifying and providing for the security needs of older people. The community garda in the area in which the woman in question resides should be in a position to advise on how the scheme is administered locally.

Qst.Quest: when the figures for the hospital waiting lists for the end of December 2002 will be published; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Martin Mr. Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy is at present being collated by my Department. The information will be forwarded to the Deputy as soon as the figures are published.

Qst.Quest: the reason the laser treatment for patients with birth marks has been cancelled at the Children's Hospital, Crumlin, Dub lin; the action that is being taken to ensure treatment is provided to patients and in particular patients who have commenced treatment; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Martin Mr. Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Services at Our Lady's Hospital for Sick Children are provided under an arrangement with the Eastern Regional Health Authority and my Department has, therefore, asked the regional chief executive of the authority to examine these matters and to reply to the Deputy directly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Autism Services.

Qst.Quest: his views on the recommendations contained in the report of the task force on autism that independent regional diagnostic assessment and intervention services for ASDs be set up in each health board area; the progress that has been made in this regard; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T. O'Malley Mr. T. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Mr. T. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: The task force on autism, which was established by the Department of Education and Science, has put forward a range of recommendations ranging from measures aimed at identifying prevalence rates, through issues relating to diagnosis and assessment, the centrality of the role of parents, the required models of education and health care services, the need for specialist training for those involved in service provision, to structural, constitutional and policy issues. The scope of the task force's recommendations is such as to require a multi-faceted response involving educational and health care inputs. The task force's recommendations are currently being considered by both Departments.

There has been a significant investment in both health related and educational supports for persons with autism in recent years. Additional funding of €13.3 million has been allocated by my Department to services for persons with autism or intellectual disability in 2003 to meet the full year cost of the 2002 developments and to further enhance the health related support services to children with autism or intellectual disability. This funding is in addition to the very significant revenue investment, amounting to €188 million, which has been made in these services since 1997 and which is built into the ongoing budget base.

MainHeading.P: The additional funding provided by this and the previous Government between 2000 and 2002 was used to put in place, in addition to a range of other services, over 900 new residential, 380 new respite and around 2,000 new day places for people with autism and those with an intellectual disability. In particular €14.6 million has been invested by my Department in health related support services for children with autism or intellectual disability nationally between 1998 and 2002. This includes diagnostic and assessment services, early intervention, home support and out reach support to children of school-going age. The health boards have been developing regional diagnostic and assessment services and these are at varying stages of development. My Department has asked the health boards and the Eastern Regional Health Authority for the detailed information requested by the Deputy and it will be forwarded to him as soon as it becomes available.

P.i: Question No. 308 answered with Question No. 302.

Qst.Quest: if he will provide details of annual volumes and cost per gallon of hydrofluorosilicic acid imported by a company (details supplied) on behalf of the Eastern Regional Health Authority from a company (details supplied); and the reason the suppliers were changed from a company (details supplied) in Rotterdam.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Martin Mr. Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: In Ireland public water supplies are fluoridated with hydrofluorosilicic acid. Since 1990, the Eastern Health Board, now the Eastern Regional Health Authority, has acted as agent for the nation's health boards for the purchase of hydrofluorosilicic acid. The chief executive officer of the Eastern Regional Health Authority has informed me that the annual volume and cost per gallon of hydrofluorosilicic acid is 720,000 gallons at €1.09 per gallon. Hydrofluorosilicic acid is provided by Derivados Del Flour S.A. Kemira Pernis, Rotterdam, has ceased operations.

Qst.Quest: when improvements (details supplied) to the Arrow route serving County Kildare will occur; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: Iarnród Éireann informs me that the company has commenced taking delivery of 80 new diesel railcars and that all of them will be in service by the end of the year. Some of these will be used on the Dublin to Kildare service. In addition, platform lengthening at Hazelhatch and Sallins stations to accommodate eight-carriage trains and the new turnback facility at Newbridge station will all be completed by year end. The Heuston Station project, which increases the number of platforms from five to nine, will also be completed in 2003. This will enable the operation of longer trains and some additional services. As a result of these developments, peak capacity on commuter services from Kildare into Heuston Station is projected to increase by 130% in the peak hour before the end of the year.

Qst.Quest: when new diesel railcars will be introduced into service on the Maynooth suburban line; when additional frequencies will be introduced; the increased capacity which will result from these improvements; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: Irish Rail informs me that new railcars will be introduced on the Maynooth line service before end 2003. These railcars will be used to replace old carriages and to increase peak-hour capacity by approximately 25%, by increasing the length of trains to standard six and eight-car operation. An increase in the frequency of services on the Maynooth corridor is subject to the resolution of city centre capacity constraints. The Department is awaiting final proposals in this regard from Iarnród Éireann.

Qst.Quest: the cost of the recently published strategic rail review; his priorities for action as a result; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: Work on the strategic rail review was carried out by a consultancy consortium led by Booz Allen Hamilton. The consultancy costs were €649,558, including VAT, and the printing of the report has so far cost €45,115, VAT exempt. The review provides a framework within which the Government can implement and prioritise an ambitious and realistic programme for the future development of the rail passenger and rail freight sector in Ireland. It lays the foundation on which we can revitalise the railways and plan a modern and efficient transport system for the benefit of this and future generations.

The review contains a recommended investment strategy that has been broadly endorsed by the Government. While this strategy in effect constitutes the priorities for action, the Government, in adopting the review, recognised that over the 20 year period flexibility and adaptability would be required to take account of emerging land use and settlement policies. Accordingly, it is recognised that in the light of developing business for both passenger and freight traffic it is possible that the rail investment priorities might vary over time.

I have already announced that I will be establishing an implementation group that will be charged with rigorously monitoring the implementation of the rail investment programme and reporting to me quarterly on progress.

Qst.Quest: if the necessary capital has been made available to Bus Átha Cliath to facilitate fleet improvements, bus shelters and/or other facilities to meet the targets set by Government for the company; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: Since 1999 over €101 million has been made available by the Exchequer and the EU to Bus Átha Cliath for investment in garage facilities, new buses and other facilities to enable the company to expand bus services in the greater Dublin area. Since then, 484 new buses have been purchased by Bus Átha Cliath, 243 of which are additional buses. These buses have improved the quality and reliability of the fleet, as well as providing for increased services. In 2003, Bus Átha Cliath is planning to purchase a further 78 new buses. The provision of bus shelters is a matter for the company itself and Exchequer funding is not provided for it.

Qst.Quest: if the feasibility study from the south Sligo rapid transit group received by his Department in 2002 was fully considered in the recently announced strategic rail review as indicated by his predecessor (details supplied); and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brennan Mr. Brennan
Speaker.P: The strategic rail review, which I published last week, provides a strategic framework for the future development of the rail passenger and rail freight sectors in Ireland. The consultants who carried out the review considered over 150 submissions received from groups and individuals in various parts of the country during the public consultation phase. The south Sligo rail study, which was submitted to the Department in 2002, was considered by the consultants during the course of their analysis. The schemes evaluated by the consultants were selected on the basis of consideration of, among other things, existing studies and reports, reasonableness in terms of potential patronage, use of existing networks, population catchment and consistency with national policy, such as the national spatial strategy. The south Sligo scheme, as well as others listed in the report, were considered by the consultants not to be so significant as to warrant a special analysis at this stage. The consultants did recognise, however, that circumstances could change which would make a revisitation of such schemes appropriate at some time in the future.

Qst.askee: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: if consideration is being given to the provision of a Garda barracks in Adamstown, New Ross, County Wexford; if a decision has been made on the request for this service; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McDowell Mr. McDowell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. McDowell)
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that Adamstown is in the Carrickbyrne sub-district. The current strength – all ranks – of Carrickbyrne Garda station as at 8 April 2003 is two. I am further informed that, following consideration of the optimum location of the Garda station for the policing of this area, senior Garda management decided that the station should remain in Carrickbyrne. Accordingly, the move to Adamstown was not recommended. Garda management will continue to appraise the policing and administrative policy employed in Carrickbyrne and Adamstown with a view to ensuring that an efficient Garda service is maintained.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. O'Keeffe Mr. N. O'Keeffe
Qst.askee: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: if he will consider approving a second Garda position at a station (details supplied) in County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McDowell Mr. McDowell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. McDowell)
Speaker.P: I have been advised by the Garda authorities, who are responsible for the day-to-day management of resources, including personnel, that the current strength of the station referred to by the Deputy is one garda. Local Garda management is satisfied that the resources currently in place in that station are adequate to meet the present policing needs of the area. I am further informed that resources are augmented from within the district and division as required. The situation will be kept under review and when additional personnel next become available the needs of the station will be fully considered within the context of the overall needs of Garda stations throughout the country.

Qst.askee: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: if he has plans to employ extra medical and paramedical staff in prisons; if so, if he will give details of same; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McDowell Mr. McDowell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. McDowell)
Speaker.P: There are currently 88 nurses employed by the Irish Prison Service, including eight nurses who commenced training on 31 March 2003. The Irish Prison Service also employs twenty three doctors. There are vacancies for one full time and one part time doctor in the service at present. I understand that arrangements are being made to fill both of these vacancies. The question of employing more medical and paramedical staff will be kept under review.

Qst.askee: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: if he is considering the introduction of fingerprinting of non-EU foreign nationals; if so, the reasons therefor; if it will be applied to all non-EU foreign nationals equally; the statistics which exist comparing crime and fraud rates among EU nationals and non-EU nationals here; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McDowell Mr. McDowell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. McDowell)
Speaker.P: As I indicated in my replies to Parliamentary Questions Nos. 25 and 42 on 6 February 2003 and 268 on 1 April 2003, I am currently considering availing of the provision which has existed in Irish immigration law since 1946 for the fingerprinting of non-EEA nationals during the course of the registration process. My reasons therefor are set out in my replies to those questions. Were fingerprinting to become a feature of the registration process, it would not be applied on the basis of a distinction made in respect of certain non-EEA nationalities. Statistics comparing crime and fraud rates among EU nationals and non-EU nationals in the State are not compiled. However, the Garda annual reports, which have been lodged in the Oireachtas Library, contain statistics in relation to the nationality of persons prosecuted for drug offences.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Proposed Legislation.

Qst.askee: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: the reason the legislation governing prisons has not been updated since 1947; the plans he has to update this legislation; if proposed changes are to be brought in line with European standards regarding prisons; the proposed changes involved; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McDowell Mr. McDowell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. McDowell)
Speaker.P: The rules for the government of prisons 1947 provide a very detailed regulatory framework for every operational aspect of prison life and set out in considerable detail the full range of rights, duties and obligations for prisoners, prison staff and management. Draft new rules were prepared in my Department and transmitted to the Attorney General for legal drafting. The parliamentary counsel subsequently provided my Department and the Irish Prison Service, in August 2002, with a draft set of new rules in legal form. These draft rules have been the subject of detailed and extensive consultation with senior staff throughout the prison system. The observations of the Irish Prison Service on the initial 60 rules were received in my Department recently and I have been advised that comments on the balance of the rules will be provided by the service within the coming weeks.

MainHeading.P: European standards for prisons have been taken into account in the drafting of the new rules. Given that the new rules are still at draft stage, I do not consider it appropriate at this point to outline any specific changes contained in them. The rules will come into force, as a statutory instrument, as soon as possible after the text has been finalised.

Qst.askee: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: if the Land Registry Office will urgently expedite a dealing for a person (details supplied) in County Mayo; and when this will be complete.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McDowell Mr. McDowell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. McDowell)
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that this application refers to a transmission on death which was lodged on 22 January 2003 – dealing No. D2003SM000569X refers. Subject to no queries arising, the application will be completed within the next few weeks.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Garda Prosecutions.

Qst.askee: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: the number of prosecutions, convictions and closure orders obtained since the Intoxicating Liquor Act 2000 came into force; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: the number of prosecutions and convictions for the sale and supply of intoxicating liquor in licensed premises and clubs to persons who are already intoxicated; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McDowell Mr. McDowell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. McDowell)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 321 and 322 together.

I am informed by the Garda authorities that the numbers of prosecutions, convictions and closure orders obtained for the offence of selling alcohol to under age persons since the Intoxicating Liquor Act 2000 came into effect on 6 July 2000 and until 31 March 2003 are as follows:

MainHeading.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that the information requested by the Deputy regarding the number of prosecutions and convictions for the sale and supply of intoxicating liquor in licensed premises and clubs to persons who are already intoxicated is not readily available. It could only be obtained by means of the expenditure of a disproportionate amount of Garda time and resources.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the criteria used to determine the 2003 non-national roads allocations to county councils which gave increases or decreases (details supplied) to county councils over the 2002 figures; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cullen Mr. Cullen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Cullen)
Speaker.P: In determining the annual non-national road grant allocations, the objective is to resource each local authority appropriately in relation to their ongoing and special needs. This process is guided by a range of criteria, including road pavement conditions, traffic volumes, length of road network and suitability, eligibility in relation to EU co-financing and special development needs.

In addition, non-national road grants include a number of grant categories such as: discretionary maintenance and improvement and restoration maintenance grants which are block grants and predominantly mileage based; restoration improvement grants which are based on multiannual restoration programmes submitted by local authorities to the Department; and other categories which are project specific such as EU co-financed specific improvement grants scheme and the grant category non-national roads to support housing and other development.

The last category applies to 15 local authorities. It is the variation in allocations under this category in 2003 compared to 2002 which is largely responsible for the increases and decreases referred to in the question.

This multiplicity of criteria, together with the impact from year to year of projects as they advance from commencement to completion, necessarily entails divergence in the annual levels of allocation between local authorities.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if, further to Parliamentary Question No. 938 of 29 January, he has had success in relation to the discussions initiated with the landowners at the land referred to; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cullen Mr. Cullen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Cullen)
Speaker.P: The position is unchanged.

Qst.hpid: Mr. P. Breen Mr. P. Breen
Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if persons will be facilitated with the provision of a crèche in existing housing developments in an area that is already in existence with young children and the burden of title on tenant purchased property removed; the place it is proposed to house the facility in an existing local authority house which comes on the market; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cullen Mr. Cullen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Cullen)
Speaker.P: I refer to my reply to Question No. 588 of 25 March.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if he will take measures to ensure that special interest groups such as canoeists are made aware of developments at the planning stage in future.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cullen Mr. Cullen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Cullen)
Speaker.P: Revised requirements regarding public notice of intention to make a planning application were established by part 4 of the Planning and Development Regulations 2001. These include a requirement to give notice of intention to make the application in an approved newspaper, and the erection or fixing of a site notice or site notices in accordance with detailed requirements set out in the regulations. The regulations also require each planning authority to publish weekly lists of planning applications received by them.

I am satisfied these requirements provide reasonable and adequate publicity around proposed developments. It would be inappropriate to add to them at this time either in relation to the type of development mentioned in the Deputy's question or otherwise.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Benefits.

Qst.hpid: Ms O. Mitchell Ms O. Mitchell
Qst.askee: Minister for Social and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: if summer payments will be returned to a person (details supplied) who is a participant in a back to education programme, as it is most unfair to change the conditions of any programme after the programme has commenced; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mary Coughlan Mary Coughlan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social and Family Affairs (Mary Coughlan)
Speaker.P: The back to education allowance scheme is non-statutory. It is a second chance educational opportunities scheme designed to help the unemployed and other groups to improve their qualifications and to enhance their employment prospects.

MainHeading.P: A review of the basic purpose underlying my Department's back to education provisions was carried out recently. In light of this, and in view of the expenditure constraints facing us this year, the scheme has been revised.

In framing proposals to change elements of the BTEA scheme my concern was to ensure that resources should be focused where the need is greatest. In line with this payments under the scheme for the summer period have been discontinued. This was done because people who had been previously unemployed often find work opportunities either at home or abroad during the summer months. Participants in the scheme who fail to find employment during the summer may be entitled to an unemployment payment, subject to satisfying the usual qualifying conditions.

The person concerned is in the first year of a four year primary degree and will be on a break during the summer period between academic years. He is not entitled to payment of the allowance for this period.
We have ensured, in a situation where priorities had to be set and choices made, that the position of people in the greatest need of assistance under the scheme has been protected.
